initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?

It was a dark and stormy night. The rain was coming down in sheets and the wind was howling. I was huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I arrived at the pub and found her sitting at the bar. She looked upset. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. I walked home in the rain, thinking about my friend and her problems. I hoped things would get better for her soon.

It was a dark and stormy night. The rain was coming down in sheets and the wind was howling. I was huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I arrived at the pub and found her sitting at the bar. She looked upset. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. I walked home in the rain, thinking about my friend and her problems. I hoped things would get better for her soon. And that's the end of the story. I hope you enjoyed it. But what if I told you that this story is actually a metaphor for something much bigger? What if I told you that this story is actually a metaphor for the human condition? It was a dark and stormy night. The rain was coming down in sheets and the wind was howling. I was huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I arrived at the pub and found her sitting at the bar. She looked upset. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. I walked home in the rain, thinking about my friend and her problems. I hoped things would get better for her soon. And that's the end of the story. I hope you enjoyed it. The night was dark and stormy, and the rain came down in sheets. The wind howled as I huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." The night was dark and stormy, and the rain came down in sheets. The wind howled as I huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." The night was dark and stormy, and the rain came down in sheets. The wind howled as I huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. The night was dark and stormy, and the rain came down in sheets. The wind howled as I huddled in my coat, trying to stay warm. I was on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I arrived at the pub and found her sitting at the bar. She looked upset. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. I'm on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I arrived at the pub and found her sitting at the bar. She looked upset. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. I'm on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I'm on my way to meet my friend at the pub. She had texted me earlier in the day and said she needed to talk. I had a feeling it wasn't going to be good news. I arrived at the pub and found her sitting at the bar. She looked upset. "What's wrong?" I asked. "I'm just so stressed out," she said. "Work has been really tough lately." "I'm sorry to hear that," I said. "Is there anything I can do to help?" She shook her head. "I don't think so. I'm just going to have to tough it out." "Well, let me know if there's anything I can do," I said. "I'll be here for you." She smiled weakly and nodded. "Thanks. I appreciate it." We sat in silence for a few minutes. Then she said, "I have to go. I have a meeting in the morning." "Okay," I said. "Take care." She got up and left. I finished my drink and then left too. I walked home in the rain, thinking about my friend and her problems. I hoped things would get better for her soon. And that's the end of the story. I hope you enjoyed it.
